Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Deciphering Origins of Vertebrate Microfossil Bonebeds: A Comparative Taphonomic and Paleoecological Approach in the Late Cretaceous of Montana
Award.AbstractNarration:
RUI: Deciphering Origins of Vertebrate Microfossil Bonebeds: A Comparative Taphonomic and Paleoecological Approach in the Late Cretaceous of Montana.
Raymond Rogers1, Matthew Carrano2, and Kristina Curry Rogers1
1 Geology Department, Macalester College, St. Paul MN
2 Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC
Vertebrate microfossil bonebeds (VMBs) are concentrated deposits of small, disarticulated skeletal remains of diverse backboned organisms. These types of fossil deposits are common in the Mesozoic and Cenozoic terrestrial sedimentary rock record, and serve as a rich source of data on the tiniest members of ancient faunas (like mammals and amphibians). In addition, VMBs provide estimates for species diversity and relative abundance in fossil vertebrate communities. In spite of their significance for understanding fossil vertebrate biodiversity, the underlying causes for the formation of such sites remain poorly understood. Our study will focus on the Judith River Formation of north-central Montana, which preserves an abundance of VMBs in well-documented geological contexts, and thereby provides an ideal opportunity to analyze formative processes. Comparative work will be conducted in the Hell Creek Formation of eastern Montana, which also preserves abundant VMBs. Analysis of these two records will: 1) advance our understanding of the processes that generate VMBs, 2) provide a suite of tests and methods that may be employed in any VMB study; 3) yield novel insights into the composition and structure of coastal plain communities during the final stages of the Late Cretaceous; and 4) provide new data on a time of significant global change that culminates in amass extinction. The research component of this project is tightly integrated with an educational outreach component that: 1) involves a collaboration of Macalester faculty and approximately 12 undergraduate students with curatorial and collections staff at the Smithsonian Institution; 2) integrates collections related to this project into courses taught at Macalester College and into public outreach and education initiatives at the Smithsonian, both on the exhibit floor (FossiLab) and through the Evolution of Terrestrial Ecosystems website; and 3) serves as a conduit for collaborative public outreach with the Montana Bureau of Land Managemen in the Upper Missouri River Breaks National Monument.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-supported project focused on deciphering the origins of incredibly rich fossil deposits in the Late Cretaceous rock record of Montana.  We examined beds of rock termed "vertebrate microfossil bonebeds" that preserve the biological detritus that accumulated in shallow lakes and rivers during the time of the dinosaurs.  We collected and studied tens of thousands of tiny shells and bones from clams, snails, salamanders, frogs, turtles, crocodiles, fish, and dinosaurs.  We carefully described the fossils with regard to size and shape and taxonomy, and we worked to discover whether these skeletal records are faithful archives of ancient animal communities, or whether they are too biased to be of interpretive value. Our work has demonstrated that these fossil deposits are in fact high quality in situ records of ancient aquatic ecosystems, and the fossil remains can be used to reconstruct ancient freshwater communities during the Mesozoic.  Another major outcome of this project is a major revision and better understanding of the sedimentary rocks that host these amazing fossil deposits.  We can now study the fossils in a more detailed framework with new radiometric ages.  

Another important outcome of our work relates to the training of undergraduate students.  We have mentored eighteen undergraduate students over the duration of this project both in the field and in the lab.  Most of these students completed senior theses or independent projects that focus on aspects of the research.  Through student training, this project has had a significant impact on society.  Four of these students are presently in graduate programs in geology and paleontology. Three are in science education and outreach positions, and one is working for the Minnesota Geological Survey. Seven of our students are women, and three are from underrepresented groups.  All of our student collaborators are more informed about science and the scientific method because of their participation on this project.  Increasing the understanding of science is an important benefit to society. 

In summation, our NSF-funded project helped to clarify how small vertebrate fossils accumulate in ancient freshwater ecosystems.  From all indications, the abundant fossil material in our many sites accumulated in situ as the resistant remnants of the life that thrived in and around ancient aquatic environments.  Our work also advanced our understanding of the quality and interpretability of these types of fossil occurrences (particularly in relation to size and shape bias), and there is good indication that these fossil sties are reliable archives of the ancient communities represented.  Finally, this project served as an excellent vehicle for the training of undergraduate students interested in STEM careers. Through student participation, this project also advanced NSF's goal of broadening participation in the sciences.
